23. Possibly other news also reached him concerning his saithless mistress. At all events when, shortly afterward, he did return to the capital, his eyes were sully opened. Not that he now ceased to love Lesbia, for that was beyond his power, and therein lay his extremest torture. He had lost all saith in her, he knew her now to be but an abandoned prostitute, and yet he could not break the chain ol his old regard. ‘I hate and love,' he cries, ‘I know not how, but I feel the anguish ol it' (c. 85).

24. Though he was condemned still to love Lesbia, the former connection with her was now broken off, never to be renewed. Yet he has sor her words ol sorrow rather than ol scorn. Even now, as formerly (c. 104), he cannot malign her, although she has sunk so deep in degradation. In a simple, manly way he declares the fidelity os his love for her (c. 87), and the condition to which he has now been brought by her fault and not his own (c. 75).
